banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: How I fell in love with quasars, blazars and our incredible universe
videoData.socialTitle: How I fell in love with quasars, blazars and our incredible universe

recommendations.blurb: Explore current work on our high-energy universe and supermassive black holes.

recItems.blurb: I recommend this book for a comprehensive look at the high-energy universe. It is a great resource for understanding exotic objects like quasars, blazars, pulsars and more.
recItems.headline: High-Energy Astrophysics
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: For much more reading on supermassive black holes, and how we infer that every galaxy likely has one at its core, check out this site from the Space Telescope Science Institute. It’s only fitting that we honor the Hubble Space Telescope on its 25th anniversary by remembering that it helped us first understand the ubiquity of galactic, supermassive black holes.
recItems.headline: Black holes, quasars and active galaxies
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: This is an informative reference about supermassive black holes.
recItems.headline: Supermassive Black Holes in Active Galactic Nuclei
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE
recItems.note:
Luis Ho et al.
in *Encyclopedia of Astronomy and Astrophysics*, Paul Murdin (Editor)
Institute of Physics Publishing, 2001

recItems.blurb: This is a definitive text about accretion physics.
recItems.headline: Accretion Power in Astrophysics
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Juhan Frank et al.
Cambridge University Press, 2002

nodes.whoTheyAre: Jedidah Isler studies blazars — supermassive hyperactive black holes that emit powerful jet streams. They are the universe’s most efficient particle accelerators, transferring energy throughout galaxies.
nodes.whyListen:
Jedidah Isler has been staring at the stars since she was 11 or 12. But because neither her undergraduate college or the university where she got her first master’s degree offered astronomy majors, she threw herself wholeheartedly into physics. It wasn’t until she entered a doctoral program that she was able to dedicate her time to the studying the night sky. In 2014, she became the first African-American woman to receive a Ph.D in Astrophysics from Yale.
Isler studies blazars — supermassive hyperactive black holes at the center of galaxies, some of which emit powerful streams of particles. Sometimes these are oriented toward Earth, offering us a unique perspective on the physics of the universe. Isler is a Chancellor’s Faculty Fellow in Physics at Syracuse University. She participates in the Future Faculty Leader program at Harvard's Center for Astrophysics and was named a 2015 TED Fellow.
Isler is also interested in breaking down barriers that prevent many students — especially women of color — from becoming scientists. She works to make STEM accessible to new communities.

videoData.description: Jedidah Isler first fell in love with the night sky as a little girl. Now she's an astrophysicist who studies supermassive hyperactive black holes. In a charming talk, she takes us trillions of kilometers from Earth to introduce us to objects that can be 1 to 10 billion times the mass of the sun — and which shoot powerful jet streams of particles in our direction.

In a charming talk, she takes us trillions of kilometers from Earth to introduce us to objects that can be 1 to 10 billion times the mass of the sun — and which shoot powerful jet streams of particles in our direction.

cues.text: My first love was for the night sky.
Love is complicated.

You're looking at a fly-through of the 
Hubble Space Telescope Ultra-Deep Field,

one of the most distant images
of our universe ever observed.
Everything you see here is a galaxy,
comprised of billions of stars each.

And the farthest galaxy is 
a trillion, trillion kilometers away.

As an astrophysicist, I have
the awesome privilege of studying

some of the most exotic objects 
in our universe.

The objects that have captivated me 
from first crush throughout my career

are supermassive, 
hyperactive black holes.

Weighing one to 10 billion times 
the mass of our own sun,

these galactic black holes 
are devouring material,

at a rate of upwards of 
1,000 times more

than your "average" 
supermassive black hole.
(Laughter)
These two characteristics,
with a few others, make them quasars.
At the same time, the objects I study

are producing some of the most
powerful particle streams
ever observed.
These narrow streams, called jets,

are moving at 99.99 percent 
of the speed of light,
and are pointed directly at the Earth.

These jetted, Earth-pointed, hyperactive
and supermassive black holes
are called blazars, or blazing quasars.

What makes blazars so special
is that they're some of the universe's
most efficient particle accelerators,

transporting incredible amounts
of energy throughout a galaxy.

Here, I'm showing an
artist's conception of a blazar.

The dinner plate by which 
material falls onto the black hole
is called the accretion disc,
shown here in blue.

Some of that material is slingshotted
around the black hole
and accelerated to insanely high speeds
in the jet, shown here in white.
Although the blazar system is rare,

the process by which nature
pulls in material via a disk,

and then flings some of it out via a jet,
is more common.

We'll eventually zoom out of 
the blazar system

to show its approximate relationship
to the larger galactic context.

Beyond the cosmic accounting
of what goes in to what goes out,

one of the hot topics in 
blazar astrophysics right now

is where the highest-energy 
jet emission comes from.

In this image, I'm interested
in where this white blob forms

and if, as a result, there's any 
relationship between the jet
and the accretion disc material.
Clear answers to this question

were almost completely
inaccessible until 2008,

when NASA launched a new telescope
that better detects gamma ray light --

that is, light with energies
a million times higher
than your standard x-ray scan.

I simultaneously compare variations
between the gamma ray light data

and the visible light data from
day to day and year to year,
to better localize these gamma ray blobs.
My research shows that in some instances,

these blobs form much closer
to the black hole
than we initially thought.
As we more confidently localize

where these gamma ray 
blobs are forming,

we can better understand how jets
are being accelerated,

and ultimately reveal 
the dynamic processes

by which some of the most fascinating
objects in our universe are formed.
This all started as a love story.
And it still is.

This love transformed me from 
a curious, stargazing young girl
to a professional astrophysicist,
hot on the heels of celestial discovery.
Who knew that chasing after the universe

would ground me so deeply
to my mission here on Earth.

Then again, when do we ever know
where love's first flutter
will truly take us.
Thank you.
(Applause)

footnotes.annotation: Many more images from the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (HUDF) can be found on the [Hubble site] (http://hubblesite.org/gallery/album/the_universe/hubble_ultra_deep_field/). This image required 800 exposures over 400 Hubble orbits around the Earth. The total exposure time was 11.3 days between [September 2003 and January 2004] (http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/2004/07/image/a/). It was later made into a [flythrough] (http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/ap130827.html) by adding [redshift] (http://astronomy.swin.edu.au/cosmos/c/cosmological+redshift), or distance, information.

I used the phrase "trillion, trillion" because while we know that the universe is approximately 13.6 billion years old, the estimate I give in the talk is for the farthest galaxy imaged in the HUDF, not the total spatial extent of the [known universe] (https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/seuforum/howfar/index.html). The farthest galaxy in the HUDF image, which appears as a red elliptical galaxy toward the center, is estimated to be at a redshift of eight, which loosely translates into a trillion, trillion kilometers.

For a good example of “average” supermassive black holes, consider the one at the center of our own galaxy. Andrea Ghez gave a [TED Talk] (http://www.ted.com/talks/andrea_ghez_the_hunt_for_a_supermassive_black_hole?language=en) about it in 2009 and it’s still very relevant today. You can see from these [movies] (http://www.galacticcenter.astro.ucla.edu/animations.html) how she and her team used stellar orbits very near the black hole to determine its mass. Studies like these help us determine the size of nearby black holes. For more distant galaxies, we have to use more indirect methods, like measuring the relationship between how bright material outside a black hole shines and how big it is.  Here’s a recent [example] (http://www.dailygalaxy.com/my_weblog/2015/02/ancient-black-hole-discovered-12-billion-times-mass-of-the-sun.html) of that method and an accompanying *[Nature](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v518/n7540/full/nature14241.html)* article.

Here is a well-documented [luminosity-size relationship] (http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/629/1/61/pdf/0004-637X_629_1_61.pdf) paper.

As for accretion rates, the simplest models of accretion onto a black hole are dependent on mass. This rate, called the Eddington rate, is the rate at which the most material can fall onto a black hole from any direction before radiation pressure stops the infall altogether. It’s an imperfect measure because we know material doesn’t fall onto a black hole in this way, but it’s a standard, simple way of calculating the upper limit of matter infall.

Two seminal articles, one by [C. Megan Urry and Paolo Padovani] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/1995PASP..107..803U/) and one by [Robert Antonucci] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/1993ARA%26A..31..473A/), describe the unified model of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), which suggests that similar physical components like the black hole, the accretion disk and, in some cases, the relativistic jet, are randomly oriented with respect to the Earth's line of sight.

This is one of the earlier works that observed [superluminal motion in a blazar] (http://iopscience.iop.org/0067-0049/133/2/297/) — that is, motion that appears to be faster than the speed of light. 

While blazars have these highly relativistic jets that are pointed at the Earth with angles often much less than five degrees to the line of sight, they pose no threat to our planet. First, because they do not remain relativistic indefinitely, and, in fact, as these jets propagate through the galaxy, they slow down and widen. If there is enough ambient material, they can also blow [“bubbles”] (http://iopscience.iop.org/2041-8205/713/1/L74/) in the surrounding material. Many of the images I show in my talk are the wider field images of galaxies that have powerful jets, but they are many orders of magnitude beyond the blazar "zone," the region where these charged particles are accelerated and produce gamma ray light emission.

The exact process by which this jetted material goes from infall near the black hole to highly accelerated emission, i.e. particle acceleration, is still not well understood. Two seminal works on how this process takes place, one by [Roger Blandford and David Payne] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/1982MNRAS.199..883B/) and one by [Roger Blandford and Roman Znajek] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/1977MNRAS.179..433B/), respectively suggest it works by magnetic fields spinning up from the accretion disk, or by the spin of the black hole itself.

Some recent [simulations] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/2011MNRAS.418L..79T/) suggest that strong fluctuations in the magnetic density of the accretion disk can effectively increase or choke off matter infall to the black hole, and potentially regulate jet activity on very long time scales.

Other examples of this accretion disk and jet framework are found in smaller, stellar-mass binary systems, where a black hole is cannibalizing the star it's in orbit with. These so-called [x-ray binaries] (https://www-xray.ast.cam.ac.uk/xray_introduction/Blackholebinary.html), because they shine brightest in the x-rays, have black holes that are known to host accretion disks and jets. More information about their jets can be found in this paper by [Ronald A. Remillard and Jeffrey E. McClintock] (http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.astro.44.051905.092532?journalCode=astro) and this one by [Elmar G. Körding et al] (http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?arXiv:astro-ph/0608628).

Also, some [protostellar systems] (http://www.astro.princeton.edu/~jstone/pjets.html) have been shown to have outflows of varying speeds. For more, see this [paper] (http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/540/1/192).

The location of the gamma-emitting region is hotly contested, with observational and theoretical evidence supporting both near- and far-field dissipation for different flares in different sources. In addition to the results our research group found, which I’ll describe below, a few examples of both scenarios are presented in papers by [Markus Böttcher] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/2007Ap%26SS.309...95B/), [Juri Poutanen and Boris Stern] (http://iopscience.iop.org/2041-8205/717/2/L118/), [Fabrizio Tavecchio et al.] (http://mnrasl.oxfordjournals.org/content/405/1/L94), [Alan P. Marscher] (http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/780/1/87/), [Jonathan León-Tavares] (http://iopscience.iop.org/2041-8205/763/2/L36/) and [Iván Agudo et al] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/2011ApJ...726L..13A/).

More information about the Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope can be found at their [website] (http://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov). To see real data from Fermi, one can look at the [publicly accessible light curves] (http://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/lat/4yr_catalog/ap_lcs.php) (plots of intensity versus time). 

On board the Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope is the Large Area Telescope (LAT). A full listing of all the sources it's detected in the last four years can be obtained in the [LAT 4-Year Catalog] (http://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/lat/4yr_catalog/). Here is the [original paper] (http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?arXiv:1501.02003).

My research suggests that in the most energetic gamma ray flares the gamma-emitting region may be closer to the supermassive black hole than we initially thought. To find out more, read these two papers: one on using [emission-line variability to probe the blazar gamma-emitting region] (http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/804/1/7/) and one that studies the [broad-line region in Blazar 3C 454.3] (http://adslabs.org/adsabs/abs/2013ApJ...779..100I/).

Also, I should note that my research is impossible without the work of a team. You can find out more about how we do this work and see our data [here] (http://www.astro.yale.edu/smarts/glast/home.php).

As the location of this gamma-emitting region is still a matter of active debate, we have not coalesced around a consistent model. It is likely true that the location of the gamma-emitting region can change from flare to flare, since the accelerations that cause this high-energy emission are stochastic in nature (i.e. randomly determined). For more, see this [paper] (http://iopscience.iop.org/2041-8205/710/2/L126). 

The emission processes that we study in blazar astrophysics are truly dynamic, happening on time scales down to hours. There is some great work showing the progression of parsec-scale core ejections, with nice animations of the scientific data. For more, see this [paper] (http://iopscience.iop.org/1538-3881/130/4/1418/).

The mission that grounds me, even as I engage this astrophysical love affair, is access to STE(A)M education for students in general and students of color in particular. I work with many organizations, speak to a variety of groups and have begun to write about this topic as much as I can. For students already proceeding along the [STEM pathway, especially astrophysics or closely related fields] (http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=18556&page=160), my goal is to help ease the way for them, while advocating for [diverse and inclusive spaces] (http://womeninastronomy.blogspot.com/2014/11/on-plancks-law-blackbodies-and-physics.html) as they go.
